_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: 2018 submittal made with correction to 2017 submittal
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Dibrom process has been designed to prevent the release of bromine. The bromine storage tank is located within a 300-square foot concrete dike with 4-foot walls for containment. The storage tank is equipped with a high-level alarm and reductant shut-down systems that will automatically shut off supply of bromine to ensure that the level is maintained below maximum volume. The process is continually monitored and bromine monitors are located within the process and around the perimeter to detect and provide an early warning for bromine vapors. The presence will set off an audible alarm. A smaller bromine storage tank was put into service January 2011 and the RMP was updated for this reason.

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Process is monitored and controlled by DCS.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: 2018 submittal includes corrections made to 2017 submittal
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Fortress (chlorethoxyfos) process has been designed to prevent the release of chlorine and hydrogen sulfide. The process is continually monitored and the equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards. Chlorine is delivered in 2,000-pound cylinders and, within a secured, covered structure that provides protection from extreme heat and direct sunlight, are stored in racks capable of holding 12 cylinders. Stationary chlorine sensors surround areas of chlorine usage (within the process and around the perimeter) to detect releases and provide an early warning for either chlorine or H2S vapors. This includes the chlorine storage area and the chlorine charging area. These sensors will activate alarms if unsafe levels are detected. Control room operators monitor this and will initiate response if necessary. The chlorine delivery system is equipped with automatic emergency shut-off devices actuated by a signal from dedicated local chlorine sensors. The system also includes a shut-off valve in the chlorine line to the reactor that will not open unless the upstream pressure is greater than the downstream pressure (backflow prevention).  Rupture discs are provided to prevent piping from rupture due to hydrostatic pressure buildup between blocked valves.





Amvac has not produced Fortress (chlorethoxyfos) since 2013 and will update all procedures, training, and PHA before next production campaign.

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Process is monitored by distributed controls
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: 2018 submittal includes corrections made to 2017 submittal
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: external Inspection of VP161 K500 Recycle tank
_prev_prog_3.Description: The K500/K550 process has been designed to prevent the release of phosphorus trichloride. The phosphorus trichloride tank is located within an 855-square foot concrete dike with 4-foot walls. The process is continually monitored and the equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards.

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: process is controlled by Distributed Control System
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: VP305 MMA Day tank - Internal Inspection
_prev_prog_3.Description: The METAM/KPAM processes have been designed to prevent the release of carbon disulfide or methylamine. The carbon disulfide storage tank is located within a 6,080-square foot concrete dike with a 2.5-foot wall for containment. The carbon disulfide storage tank is equipped a high-level alarm that will automatically close valves in the unload line. The process is continually monitored. The unload pump will shut down upon low flow conditions (dry run protection). Loss of instrument air, electricity, or nitrogen will also result in shutdown of unloading operations. Temperature indicators will alarm if high temperature boundaries are met. Area monitors are present to detect vapor releases, which will activate alarms located in the control room. Vapors are routed through a scrubber and then to a vent gas incinerator for emission control. As an additional measure, operators maintain 3 ? 4 inches of water in the containment dike. Since carbon disulfide is heavier than water, this ensures that any leaks of carbon disulfide will be submersed in water to minimize vaporization. The MMA storage tanks are located within a concrete dike for containment and have been pre-charged with water. Both MMA storage tanks are equipped with a high-level alarm and have pressure switches capable of shutting down pumps associated with the tanks. Area monitors are present to detect vapor releases, which will activate alarms located in the control room. Temperature sensors will activate an alarm if high temperature boundaries are exceeded. Both tanks are equipped with a fire suppression system, capable of soaking the area with a water and foam mixture. The MMA discharge valves are equipped with fusable links which will disconnect the air supply in the event of a fire allowing the valves to fail closed.

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: process is monitored and controlled by distributed control system
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: 2018 submittal includes correction made to 2017 submittal
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Nemacur process has been designed to prevent the release of Isopropylamine. The process is continually monitored via distributed control system and the equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards. The Isoproplyamine storage tank is located within a containment dike that has adequate containment capacity. Process vapors are controlled in a closed vent system to onsite incinerator.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: 2018 submittal includes corrections made to 2017 submittal
_prev_prog_3.Description: The DMCAA process includes the use of chlorine as a raw material. Chlorine is delivered in 2,000-pound cylinders and, within a secured, covered structure that provides protection from extreme heat and direct sunlight, are stored in racks capable of holding 12 cylinders. Stationary chlorine sensors surround areas of chlorine usage to detect releases. These sensors will detect any release, and activate alarms if unsafe levels are detected. Control room operators monitor this and initiate response if necessary. The chlorine delivery system is equipped with automatic emergency shut-off devices actuated by a signal from dedicated local chlorine sensors. The delivery system also includes a shutoff valve in the chlorine line to the reactor which will not open unless the upstream pressure is greater than the downstream pressure (backflow prevention). Rupture discs are provided to prevent piping from rupture due to hydrostatic pressure buildup between blocked valves.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: 2018 submittal includes corrections made to 2017 submittal
_prev_prog_3.Description: Phosphite is a raw material used in the Tribufos process at the Axis Alabama facility. AMVAC began manufacturing phosphite onsite in March, 2017 and phosphorous trichloride is a raw material for this phosphite production. This process has been designed to prevent the release of phosphorus trichloride. The process is continually monitored via distributed control system and the equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards. The PCL3 storage tank (VP162) is located within an 855-square foot concrete containment dike with 4-foot walls that has adequate containment capacity. Process vents are controlled in a closed vent system that vents to an onsite gas incinerator.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management plan has been prepared for the Amvac pesticide manufacturing facility at 12650 Highway 43 North, in Axis Alabama. The plan has been prepared in accordance with the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule 40 CFR Part 68. RMP requires facilities that use extremely hazardous substances to develop a Risk Management Plan. These plans must be revised and resubmitted to EPA every five years. 



The Amvac facility was originally a portion of the Dupont Manufacturing Center (Now FMC). It was purchased from Dupont by Amvac on 5-18-2001. Amvac is considered a tenant on the FMC (formerly Dupont) site at Axis Alabama. All site Emergency Response is mutually shared and coordinated by the emergency response teams from both companies. 



Amvac's Axis facility receives steam, fire water, process water, potable water and air from the FMC (formerly Dupont) facility. Amvac's facility consists of various buildings, chemical reactors, above ground storage tanks and vessels (inside containment), truck loading/unloading stations, railcar unloading stations and various ancillary equipment. 



The Amvac Axis facility has a North American industrial Classification System (NAICS) Code of 32532 for Pesticide and Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing. The plant manufactures pesticides which require the handling of Acutely Hazardous Materials in quantities which make them subject to the Risk Management Rule requirements of the Clean Air Act (40 CFR 68).



40 CFR 68.190 outlines requirements for submitting updates to the RMP. Amvac's most recent submittal was certified and sent to EPA on February 21, 2017. Amvac's 5 Year Anniversary date is currently February 21, 2022. This is the date by which the next full RMP re-submission must be completed. 



The listed Toxic substances include:

1.    Chlorine; CAS# 7782-50-5 used in Fortress (chlorethoxyfos) and DMCAA processes

2.    Phosphorus Trichloride; CAS# 7719-12-2 used in Fortress (chlorethoxyfos), K500 and Phosphite processes

3.    Hydroge

n Sulfide; CAS# 7783-06-4 used in Fortress (chlorethoxyfos) process (This is below threshold)

4.    Bromine; CAS# 7726-95-6 used in Dibrom/Naled process

5.    Carbon Disulfide; CAS# 75-15-0 used in Metam/Kpam processes



The Listed Flammable Substances include:

1.    Methylamine; CAS# 74-89-5 used in Metam/Kpam processes

2.    Isopropylamine (2-Propanamine) ; CAS 75-31-0 used in Nemacur process



Worst Case Scenario and Alternate Case Scenario for covered Toxic Substances:



RMP*Comp has been used to complete Off-site consequence analysis for all RMP covered chemicals at Amvac's Axis Alabama facility. As per 40 CFR 68.22 (c) and because AMVAC uses the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance through RMP*Comp, AMVAC has evaluated the worst case release analyses with RMP*Comp assumptions of 25 degrees C and 50% humidity as values for the temperature and humidity variables. Per 40 CFR 68.22(g), the highest maximum temperature at Mobile regional Airport since 2015 was used for the temperature of the released substance.  That temperature occurred on July 19, 2015, with a reading of 98 degrees F. This information was obtained from Corey Bunn, Meteorologist at Coastal Weather Research Center, Mobile Alabama. 



The one worst case release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance to an endpoint for toxicity is from the release of carbon disulfide. Assumptions for this scenario include a complete release of the contents of the carbon disulfide (CS2) storage tank (V303). Carbon Disulfide is loaded from iso-containers and railcars into V303. 



RMP*Comp input parameters for worst case scenario modeling include 315,000 pounds of carbon disulfide released into its surrounding concrete dike of 6,080 square feet and 2.5 ft. wall, and maximum temperature of 98 degrees F. The resulting distance in any direction to an endpoint was calculated to be 5.0 miles. This distance is at least a half-mile further to a toxic endpoint than any other RMP-regulated chemical.



An e

vent of this nature is very unlikely due to process controls described in this report. There are several safeguards in place to prevent a scenario such as this. Level alarms associated with the carbon disulfide storage tank will alarm on high level and will automatically close valves in the unload line. The unload pump will shut down on low flow (dry run protection) and loss of instrument air, electricity or nitrogen will also result in shutdown of unloading operations.  Temperature indicators will alarm if high temperature boundaries are met. Area monitors are present to detect vapor release, and they will activate alarms located in the control room. Vapors are routed through a scrubber and then to a vent gas incinerator for emission control. As an additional measure, operators maintain 3 - 4 inches of water in the V303 containment dike. Since carbon disulfide is heavier than water, this ensures that any leaks of carbon disulfide will be submersed in water to minimize vaporization.



An alternate release scenario for carbon disulfide (CS2) is one that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario. This would be a leak that develops in the CS2 transfer line from the storage tank to the reactor. It takes approximately 50 minutes to transfer CS2 into the reactor. Assuming a leak rate of 4 gallons per minute and 50 minutes release time, this leak would result in 200 gallons of carbon disulfide spilling onto the concrete floor. RMP*Comp dispersion model was used for this alternative scenario. A total of 200 gallons (2,080 pounds) of carbon disulfide were released, and the estimated downwind distance to the toxic endpoint was 0.2 miles. There are no public receptors within this area.



The 104,000-pound bromine storage tank (V126) is surrounded by a concrete dike size of 300 square feet, with 4-foot walls, and is equipped with a high-level alarm and reductant shut-down systems that will automatically shut off supply of bromine to ensure that the level is maintai

ned below maximum volume. Bromine monitors are located within the process and around the perimeter to detect and provide an early warning for bromine vapors. The presence will set off an audible alarm.



An alternate release scenario for bromine would be from a process pipe leak, from failures at a flange or weld. It takes approximately 16 hours to charge bromine into the reactor. It is assumed that such a leak would result in 20 gallons of bromine released during the transfer (0.527 pounds per minute) from the storage tank into the reactor. At 26 pounds per gallon, this would be 500 pounds of bromine released. According to RMP*Comp, the estimated distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.1 miles. There are no public receptors within this area.



The Phosphorus Trichloride storage tank (VP162 @ 132,000 pounds) is within a concrete dike of 855 square feet, with 4-foot walls. The equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards. Process vents are controlled in a closed vent system that vents to an onsite gas incinerator.



The alternate scenario for a phosphorus trichloride release is a process pipe leak in the transfer line from the storage tank to the reactor, which takes about 5.75 hours. It was assumed that 200 gallons of phosphorus trichloride were released during this time. RMP*Comp results indicated an estimated distance to the toxic endpoint is <0.1 miles. There are no public receptors within this area.



Chlorine is used in DMCAA and Fortress (chlorethoxyfos) processes. Chlorine is delivered in 2,000-pound cylinders and stored in racks capable of holding 12 cylinders. The cylinders are stored in a secured, covered structure that provides protection from extreme heat and direct sunlight. The equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards.



Stationary chlorine sensors surround areas of chlorine usage to detect releases. This includes the chlorine storage area a

nd the chlorine charging area. These sensors will activate alarms if unsafe levels are detected. Control room operators monitor this and will initiate response if necessary. The chlorine delivery system is equipped with automatic emergency shut-off devices actuated by a signal from dedicated local chlorine sensors. The system also includes a shut-off valve in the chlorine line to the reactor which will not open unless the upstream pressure is greater than the downstream pressure (backflow prevention). Rupture discs are provided to prevent piping from rupture due to hydrostatic pressure buildup between blocked valves.



The alternate scenario for a chlorine release is a process pipe leak from failure at the load flange, resulting in 150 pounds of chlorine released to atmosphere. Typical charging time is about 200 minutes (0.75 pounds per minute). According to RMP*Comp, an estimated distance to the toxic endpoint is less than 0.1 miles. There are no alternate scenarios having toxic endpoints offsite. 





Worst Case Scenario and Alternative Case Scenario for covered Flammable Substances:



The Worst Case Release Scenario and Alternate Case scenario for Flammable Substances are presented for Methylamine (CAS#74-89-5), which is classified as a flammable substance in Table 3 of 40 CFR 68 and is used as a raw material in the Metam/Kpam process. Methylamine (MMA) is offloaded from railcars, in gaseous state into storage tanks V301 and V302, which have been pre-charged with water. The capacity of the railcar is 160,000 pounds of anhydrous MMA. The MMA storage tanks are located within a concrete dike for containment. The worst case scenario would be a complete release of the contents of the railcar. Using RMP*Comp, an estimate of 160,000 pounds (vapor cloud explosion) with wind speed of 1.5 m/s and stability class G, @ 77F (25C), resulted in an estimated impact distance of 0.4 miles. The wind speed, temperature and stability class are assumptions used by RMP*Comp. 



An

incident of this nature is very unlikely due to many process controls in place. Both MMA storage tanks are equipped with a high-level alarm and have pressure switches capable of shutting down pumps associated with the tanks. Area monitors are present to detect vapor releases, which will activate alarms located in the control room. Temperature sensors will activate an alarm if high temperature boundaries are exceeded. Both tanks are equipped with a fire suppression system, capable of soaking the area with a water and foam mixture. The MMA discharge valves are equipped with fusable links which will disconnect the air supply in the event of a fire allowing the valves to fail closed. 



An alternative release scenario for methylamine (MMA) would be a leak during unloading operations from the railcar to the storage tanks. This could be a result improper draining during connection of transfer hoses from the railcar to the storage tank. It is assumed that 1,100 pounds would be released during a typical charging time of 150 minutes (7.33 pounds per minute). According to RMP*Comp, an estimated distance to the toxic endpoint is <0.1 miles. There are no plausible, alternate scenarios having an offsite toxic endpoint. 



Isopropylamine [2-Propanamine] (CAS#75-31-0) is a raw material used in the Nemacur process. Isopropylamine is identified as a flammable substance in Table 3 of 40 CFR 68. It is stored in storage tank V421. This tank has 8,000 gallon capacity and is located within concrete containment dike. It is delivered in tanker trailers and unloaded via seal less pump unto V421. The process is continually monitored via distributed control system and the equipment has been constructed according to recognized and accepted codes and regulatory standards. Process vapors are controlled in a closed vent system to onsite incinerator. Worst case scenario, using RMP*Comp, simulated total loss of storage tank V421. Input parameters included 46,037 pounds release, Vapor Cloud Explos

ion, Liquid Temperature 98 degrees F. Mitigation measures include diked area 425 square feet, dike height 4 feet. RMP*Comp assumptions include wind speed 1.5 meters/second, stability class F, air temperature 77 degrees F. Based on RMP*Comp output, the estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure is 0.07 miles. This is the distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 pounds per square inch specified for this regulated substance. 



An alternative release scenario involving isopropylamine was simulated using RMP*Comp. The scenario is flange leak during the transfer from the storage tank to the reactor.  Assumptions considered for this scenario include a release of 500 pounds, over 20 minute (25 pounds per minute).  According to RMP*Comp, an estimated distance to the toxic endpoint is <0.1 miles. There are no plausible, alternate scenarios having an offsite toxic endpoint. 

There are no public receptors within this area.





The Five Year Accident History

There have been no 40 CFR 68.42 accidents involving acutely hazardous Materials since the acquisition of the Axis plant by Amvac.



Amvac's Emergency Response Program:

Amvac Chemical Corporation has adopted an implemented an Emergency Response Plan at the Amvac manufacturing facility located at 12650 Highway 43 North, Axis Alabama, for the purpose of handling emergency situations in such a manner as to minimize the risks to life, environment, and property.



The Amvac Axis facility was originally a portion of the FMC (Formerly Dupont) Mobile Manufacturing Center. It was purchased from FMC (Formerly Dupont) by Amvac on May 18, 2001. The Amvac Axis facility and the FMC (Formerly Dupont) facility are on a common site. All Emergency Response is mutually shared and coordinated by the emergency response teams from both companies.



The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for handling releases and spills of hazardous materials in any area and contains specific emergency procedures for bomb threat, firefighting, eme

rgency alarm activation, evacuation, offsite emergencies, local area emergency notification, government agency notification and hurricanes. Amvac conducts inspections of the facility and the equipment, and emergency response drills are conducted.



The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed annually and/or when:

a)    There has been a major change in the facility chemicals and or plant operation that changes the potential for fires and the release of hazardous substance, such that a change in the response is needed for any emergency.

b)    The plan fails in an emergency.

c)    There is a change of emergency coordinator/responders.

d)    There is a change of emergency equipment.



Any incident or emergency which results in a chemical release is reported to the following agencies as applicable: Mobile County Emergency management Agency, Alabama Emergency Response Commission, Alabama Department of Environmental Management (ADEM), National Response Center (NRC), Coast Guard Marine Safety Office, Mobile, Mobile County Sheriff, Alabama State Troopers. Any reportable serious work-related injury, illness or death is reported to the OSHA office immediately, but no longer than 8 hours after the employer's knowledge of the incident. All such incidents will be reviewed and investigated as to its cause and method for future prevention.



All plant personnel receive training on the implementation of the emergency response plan upon hire, upon changes in the plan and periodic refresher training on the various aspects of the plan.



As per 29 CFR 1910.120 (q)(6); Training shall be based on the duties and function to be performed by each responder of an emergency response organization. The skill and knowledge levels required for all new responders, those hired after the effective date of this standard, shall be conveyed to them through training before they are permitted to take part in actual emergency operations on an incident. First responders at the awareness level are individuals who a

re likely to witness or discover a hazardous substance release and who have been trained to initiate an emergency response sequence by notifying the proper authorities of the release. They would take no further action beyond notifying the authorities of the release. First responders at the operations level are individuals who respond to releases or potential releases of hazardous substances as part of the initial response to the site for the purpose of protecting nearby persons, property, or the environment from the effects of the release. They are trained to respond in a defensive fashion without actually trying to stop the release. Their function is to contain the release from a safe distance, keep it from spreading, and prevent exposures. First responders at the operational level shall have received at least eight hours of training or have had sufficient experience to objectively demonstrate competency in the following areas in addition to those listed for the awareness level and the employer shall so certify:



(A) Knowledge of the basic hazard and risk assessment techniques.

(B) Know how to select and use proper personal protective equipment provided to the first responder operational level.

(C) An understanding of basic hazardous materials terms.

(D) Know how to perform basic control, containment and/or confinement operations within the capabilities of the resources and personal protective equipment available with their unit.

(E) Know how to implement basic decontamination procedures.

(F) An understanding of the relevant standard operating procedures and termination procedures.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Amvac Axis has an ongoing program to consider and address any employee related issues and suggestions. Amvac will continue to improve the safety performance accordingly.
